Add some example for Webkit

note.body:
I don't want to add a chapter with even short descriptions of WebKit and other
subroutine libraries that can be used together with gtkmm. I guess there are many
other such libraries.

I can store your example in the gtkmm-documentation/examples/others directory,
if you like. But only if you can tell me why it doesn't work when I test it.
If you've ever used WebKit, you know more about it than I do.
```
bwrap: setting up uid map: Permission denied

** (example:7570): ERROR **: 15:29:01.488: Failed to fully launch dbus-proxy: Child process exited with code 1
```
It will only be conditionally built by `ninja examples` or `ninja test`, only if
webkitgtk is installed. Gtkmm-documentation shall not depend on webkitgtk.

target_title: Add some example for program internationalization and localization

note.body:
I've added an example, similar to your example. My version uses TextView instead of Label.

I don't understand what explanation you want to have added. There is a whole
chapter *27. Internationalization and Localization*, explaining this stuff.
It contains several links to more explanation. Unfortunately it's difficult.
How to do it depends to some extent on where your translatable strings are located:
In C or C++ code, in XML (.ui) files, etc. It also depends on which build
system you use: Autotools, meson, other, none.

note.body:
> where did you find the `output.quietly` parameter? I

From https://www.mail-archive.com/dblatex-users@lists.sourceforge.net/msg00074.html (via Google)

> I can't find the added comments.

They are in `meson.build`. I thought that would be explicit than a git commit message, which one has to search git history for.

```meson
# highlight.js files were downloaded from
# https://highlightjs.org/download. Choose 'cpp' option (which
# contains only C++ related files) and click 'Download'. This should
# download a .zip containing .js and huge set of .css files (like
# 'intellij-light.min.css' etc). 'highlight.min.css' is actually
# 'intellij-light.min.css'.
style_files = [
  'style.css',
  'highlight.js/highlight.min.css',
  'highlight.js/highlight.min.js',
]
```

> If you want to remove those extra newlines, please do.

Okay. I'll update this MR.

> Probably we don't. Anyway it's not important, and not worth much effort, at least not before someone insists that it's useful.

Agree.

Yes, that would be fine. I just wonder, where did you find the `output.quietly`
parameter? I don't find it at `dblatex.sourceforge.net/doc/manual/`, nor in the
`DocBook to LaTeX Publishing manual` shipped with `dblatex` 0.3.12 in Ubuntu 24.04,
although `dblatex` 0.3.12 understands it and suppresses most messages.
Not even Google is very helpful here.

I can't find the added comments.

If you want to remove those extra newlines, please do.

Probably we don't. Anyway it's not important, and not worth much effort, at least
not before someone insists that it's useful.

target_title: Add support for code syntax highlighting in HTML

note.body:
> When I did, I got a PDF file without syntax highlighting.

The real question here is do we really want syntax highlighting in PDF ?

I looked into a few online PDF programming books and while they offer illustration images in color, the code is always `monospace` black / gray. I'm sure there is some reasoning behind that.

Just something to think about before spending time / effort in that direction.

target_title: Add support for code syntax highlighting in HTML

note.body:
As mentioned in one of the commits messages, some code snippets start in a new line, which will have extra empty space on top as in https://sid.pages.gitlab.gnome.org/-/gtkmm-documentation/-/jobs/4431783/artifacts/_build/docs/installed-tutorial/html/sec-basics-gobj-and-wrap.html.

### Extra space:

```xml
<programlisting>
Gtk::Button button("example");
gtk_button_do_something_that_gtkmm_cannot(button.gobj());
</programlisting>
```

### Extra space removed:

```xml
<programlisting>Gtk::Button button("example");
gtk_button_do_something_that_gtkmm_cannot(button.gobj());
</programlisting>
```

I can add a commit to this MR, if that's ok.

target_title: Add support for code syntax highlighting in HTML

note.body:
### Background: Here we explain how this MR works, which is needed to understand a few related issues. We're achieving syntax highlighting in HTML pages by using `highlight.js` (which uses a totally different approach to syntax highlighting than supported by docbook/XSL). We're trying to get the following tag structure in `index.docbook` for all example code / snippets. ```xml actual code ` ``` which gets modified / transformed to ```xml 
  
     actual code
``` when `index.docbook` is converted to HTML files via `xsltproc`. And `highlight.js` enables syntax highlighting of code within the `
..
` tags. So, when a HTML file (say, `sec-checkbuttons.html`) is loaded in browser, `highlight.js` script loads the code within `
` and highlights in at runtime. This can be easily seen in the content difference between the actual HTML file (say, `sec-checkbuttons.html`) opened in an editor, and viewed by the `View Page Source` option in browser.

This is demonstrated below for `sec-checkbuttons.html`.

#### Contents when opened in text editor:

```html


#ifndef GTKMM_EXAMPLE_BUTTONS_H
#define GTKMM_EXAMPLE_BUTTONS_H
...
...



```

#### Contents when opened in `View Page Source` in browser:

```html


#ifndef GTKMM_EXAMPLE_BUTTONS_H
#define GTKMM_EXAMPLE_BUTTONS_H
...
...



```

### Inferences:

1. This means that we're modifying `index.docbook` to achieve the styling in HTML files, but `index.docbook` itself doesn't have any style on its own. `index.docbook` styling is needed to achieving syntax highlighting in PDF / PS etc. But that's quite an involved task as one needs to understand docbook in more detail. So, that means syntax highlighting in PDF is not covered by this MR.

2. The `code: default template used in programlisting or screen` messages are hints from `dblatex` indicating that `index.docbook` has ` ... ` entries, but doesn't provide any linked XSL stylesheet information for `` tags. This means the default template (which is no styling) is being used, which means that these tags will not make any difference visually, and hence `dblatex` is hinting if this is a mistake (no-op) in code, which is not the case here.

3. Even without this MR, `dblatex` emits the following similar hints:

   ```
   application: default template used in programlisting or screen
   application: default template used in programlisting or screen
   function: default template used in programlisting or screen
   function: default template used in programlisting or screen
   ```

   If required, these hints can be suppressed by using the following patch:

   ```diff
   --- a/tools/meson_aux/tutorial-custom-cmd.py
   +++ b/tools/meson_aux/tutorial-custom-cmd.py
   @@ -202,6 +202,7 @@ def dblatex():
        '-P', 'toc.section.depth=1',
        '-P', 'paper.type=a4paper',
        '-P', 'doc.collab.show=1',
   +    '-P', 'output.quietly=1',
        '-P', 'latex.output.revhistory=0',
      ]
      figures_dir_parent = os.path.dirname(figures_dir)
```

target_title: Add support for code syntax highlighting in HTML

note.body:
Don't bother with `autotools` unless it's trivial. I've checked that it's still
possible to build with autotools. The example code looks the same as before.
That's okay. I hope people don't use autotools much nowadays.

The example code (created with meson) looks much better now. Just a few comments for now.

I suppose you've copied the highlight.min.js and highlight.min.css files from somewhere.
It would be fine to have comments in the files telling from where they have been copied.
Might be useful if they must be updated in the future.

It's possible to build a PDF file by setting the meson option build-pdf=true.
When I did, I got a PDF file without syntax highlighting. I also got a lot of messages:
```
[1/1] Generating docs/tutorial/C-pdf with a custom command
Build the book set list...
Build the listings...
XSLT stylesheets DocBook - LaTeX 2e (0.3.12)
===================================================
Stripping NS from DocBook 5/NG document.
Processing stripped document.
code: default template used in programlisting or screen
code: default template used in programlisting or screen
code: default template used in programlisting or screen
code: default template used in programlisting or screen
code: default template used in programlisting or screen

         ------- hundreds of such lines -------

Build index.docbook.pdf
'programming-with-gtkmm.pdf' successfully built
```

target_title: Add support for code syntax highlighting in HTML

If yes, it would be great if someone can add that, as I always seem to spend non-trivial amount of time on anything involving `autotools`.

note.body:
Please ignore this comment, as this issue is resolved. 

This MR involves patching the HTML files (refer diff below) generated from docbook (via `xsltproc`). This might not be the best approach. This is explained in the commit message. I just wanted to discuss this point, before we proceed with possible merging. Hence, starting a thread.


```diff
--- a/changes-gtkmm3.html	2024-10-24 14:44:56.397264926 +0100
+++ b/changes-gtkmm3.html	2024-10-24 14:53:46.752548902 +0100
@@ -1,5 +1,12 @@
 <html>
 <head>
+  <link rel="stylesheet" href="highlight.min.css">
+  <script src="highlight.min.js"></script>
+  <script>
+    hljs.configure({languages: ['cpp']});
+    hljs.highlightAll();
+  </script>
+  
 <meta http-equiv="Content-Type" content="text/html; charset=UTF-8">
 <title>Chapter 4. Changes in gtkmm 3</title>
 <link rel="stylesheet" type="text/css" href="style.css">
--- a/changes-gtkmm4.html	2024-10-24 14:44:56.473263330 +0100
+++ b/changes-gtkmm4.html	2024-10-24 14:53:46.708549482 +0100
@@ -1,5 +1,12 @@
 <html>
 <head>
+  <link rel="stylesheet" href="highlight.min.css">
+  <script src="highlight.min.js"></script>
+  <script>
+    hljs.configure({languages: ['cpp']});
+    hljs.highlightAll();
+  </script>
+  
 <meta http-equiv="Content-Type" content="text/html; charset=UTF-8">
 <title>Chapter 5. Changes in gtkmm-4.0 and glibmm-2.68</title>
```

target_title: Add syntax highlighting for example source code

note.body:
FWIW, here is the HTML code snippet from https://sid.pages.gitlab.gnome.org/gnome-software-help/software-metadata.html, where XML syntax highlighting works, as it has proper XML syntax highlighting code `class` set (as shown below). ```xml 
  
    xml code ....
``` The above html page was generated from the following mallard page in [software-metadata.page#L249-259](https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/gnome-software/-/blob/main/help/C/software-metadata.page#L249-259). I've used mallard (where `yelp-build html` command is used to generate HTML from mallard pages), but not DocBook. But, I assume there should be an equivalent way to add syntax language in the docbook code, which should generate something like below. ```xml ```
